content:
No, the policy of unrestricted submarine warfare is a well-documented historical event, and there is extensive evidence from various sources that confirms its existence and impact.

While there was no specific treaty or document outlining the policy, there are numerous primary sources, such as government documents, speeches, and letters, that describe the policy and its implementation. In addition, there are many secondary sources, such as historical accounts and academic research, that analyze the policy and its impact on the war.

Historians and scholars have studied the policy of unrestricted submarine warfare in depth and have drawn their conclusions based on a thorough examination of the available evidence. While there may be differing interpretations of the evidence, the existence of the policy and its impact on the war are widely accepted historical facts.
